title: Baby boy died after just 25 days - now his parents want to give something back to hospital that treated him
text:

A heartbroken couple are trying to do something positive with their grief - by helping buy new equipment for the neonatal unit which cared for their tragic son. 
Ingrid and Andy Platt-Chance enjoyed 25 precious days with their son Freddie, who was born with a range of serious health problems. 
Despite the efforts of nurses and doctors St Mary’s Hospital in Manchester, the newborn lost his fight for life on January 13. 
His mum and dad are now hoping to raise £5,000 for new equipment at the hospital’s 59 cot-space unit - as well as support its bereavement team. 
And in just a single day, the couple from Offerton, Stockport, have raised half their target after sharing their story with others. 
Ingrid and Andy knew during her pregnancy that their son was fighting the odds to survive. Specialists decided his best chance was to be delivered by c-section seven weeks early, and he was rushed immediately to the hospital’s Neonatal Intensive Care Unit. Little Freddie was born with a range of serious health problems and died aged just 25 days old (Photo: UGC) 
He was diagnosed with a congenital heart defect, multiple cysts in his lungs, and persistent swelling and fluid throughout his body. 
Mum Ingrid said: “Every day the NICU team would work tirelessly to help Freddie survive and find answers. Constantly thinking of more ideas, tests, investigations, blood transfusions, higher settings for his ventilation, bigger consultant discussions. Freddie had everyone fighting for him.” 
Andy, 33, said that although doctors had seen Freddie’s problems and conditions before, they had never come across them all in the same child at the same time. 
He added: “They’d never seen anything like this before, they’d seen everything individually but not all present in one child. 
“On January 11 we got a call saying we needed to get to the hospital. We knew then that his days were numbered. 
“Every time he suffered, it would take the nurse a long time to stabilise him, and we realised that there was little if nothing else that could be done for him. 
“We told the doctor that the next time he showed us he couldn’t fight to let him go. 
“It was an incredibly painful decision that no parent should ever have to make but we had to put our own feelings aside and do what was right for Freddie.” Freddie's mum and dad are now hoping to raise £5,000 for new equipment at St Mary’s Hospital in Manchester (Photo: UGC) 
After Freddie passed away, his family were able to take him into a special room at the hospital where they could dress him and spend time together as a family. 
Andy described the bereavement service as fantastic, saying the support they received during that difficult time was ‘invaluable’. 
He said: “They couldn’t have done enough, the staff really were incredible. Not just with Freddie and us, but also his older sister Ava, who is three. 
“Nothing was too much. When he died we went into this special room which was set up like a nursery, there were wardrobes full of clothes and toys, they even brought us a camera with an SD card so we could take photographs as a memory. 
“This entire service is funded by donations and we want to raise money to support that, as well as help pay towards new equipment for the NICU.” 
A GoFundMe page was launched on Tuesday, and has already raised more than £2,400. The family hope to continue raising money in Freddie’s memory with future fundraising events. 
To support their campaign, visit www.justgiving.com/crowdfunding/ingrid-platt-chance . Like us on Facebook
